articles.headline: Los Angeles Mayor Sets Sights on a Bigger Stage
articles.snippet: A reappraisal of Antonio R. Villaraigosa is under way amid signs that he is orchestrating a shift in his political fortunes as his term ends.
articles.abstract: A reappraisal of Antonio R. Villaraigosa is under way amid signs that he is orchestrating a shift in his political fortunes as his term ends.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Antonio R. Villaraigosa was elected mayor of this city in 2005 on a wave of excitement that began collapsing within two years, as he confessed to an extramarital affair with a television reporter, struggled to run City Hall amid an economic downturn and disappointed supporters who thought he was drawn to the glamour, rather than the grit, of the job.

articles.headline: J.& J. Chief to Resign One Role
articles.snippet: William C. Weldon will step down as chief executive of Johnson & Johnson, which has struggled to emerge from a swarm of product recalls and manufacturing lapses.
articles.abstract: William C. Weldon will step down as chief executive of Johnson & Johnson, which has struggled to emerge from a swarm of product recalls and manufacturing lapses.
articles.lead_paragraph: William C. Weldon, who presided over Johnson & Johnson during one of the most tumultuous periods in its history, will step down as chief executive in April, the company announced Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: Hip Maker Discussed Failures
articles.snippet: Before recalling an all-metal artificial hip, Johnson & Johnson insisted it was safe and maintained that company-sponsored studies refuted complaints that the device was flawed.
articles.abstract: Before recalling an all-metal artificial hip, Johnson & Johnson insisted it was safe and maintained that company-sponsored studies refuted complaints that the device was flawed.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year before recalling an artificial hip, an executive at Johnson & Johnson reported in an internal e-mail that the Food and Drug Administration had refused to approve the device, after reviewing company studies that showed it had failed prematurely in “significant” numbers, requiring repeat surgeries for patients.

articles.headline: In Republican Race, a New Breed of Superdonor
articles.snippet: About two dozen couples, individuals, or corporations have given $1 million or more to “super PACs” this year, making them easily the most influential donors in politics today.
articles.abstract: About two dozen couples, individuals, or corporations have given $1 million or more to “super PACs” this year, making them easily the most influential donors in politics today.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last June, Harold C. Simmons, a wealthy Texas businessman, sent a $100,000 check to Americans for Rick Perry, a “super PAC” preparing for Mr. Perry’s entry into the presidential race. A few months later, he donated $1 million to a different pro-Perry group through his company. In December, as Mr. Perry’s fortunes waned, Mr. Simmons wrote another check, this one for $500,000, to Winning Our Future, a super PAC supporting Newt Gingrich.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore, Michael Luo and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: In Din Over Iran, Rattling Sabers Echo
articles.snippet: Talk of war over Iran’s nuclear program has reached a strident pitch in recent weeks, with threats from Israel of a possible strike, bellicose American oratory and defiance from Tehran.
articles.abstract: Talk of war over Iran’s nuclear program has reached a strident pitch in recent weeks, with threats from Israel of a possible strike, bellicose American oratory and defiance from Tehran.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has now endured what by some measures is the longest period of war in its history, with more than 6,300 American troops killed and 46,000 wounded in Iraq and Afghanistan and the ultimate costs estimated at $3 trillion. Both wars lasted far longer than predicted. The outcomes seem disappointing and uncertain.

articles.headline: Legal Fees Mount at Fannie and Freddie
articles.snippet: As expenses rise, there are new calls to limit the costs at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and outlays for defending its former executives.
articles.abstract: As expenses rise, there are new calls to limit the costs at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and outlays for defending its former executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Taxpayers have advanced almost $50 million in legal payments to defend former executives of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in the three years since the government rescued the giant mortgage companies, a regulatory analysis has found.

articles.headline: Obama Offers to Cut Corporate Tax Rate to 28%
articles.snippet: President Obama plans to propose a reduction in business taxes in return for eliminating dozens of loopholes and subsidies.
articles.abstract: President Obama plans to propose a reduction in business taxes in return for eliminating dozens of loopholes and subsidies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will ask Congress to scrub the corporate tax code of dozens of loopholes and subsidies to reduce the top rate to 28 percent, down from 35 percent, while giving preferences to manufacturers that would set their maximum effective rate at 25 percent, a senior administration official said on Tuesday.
